citations.narrative:
The perimeter fence line adjacent to one primary enclosure at the facility still remains less than six feet tall. This vacant
primary enclosure serves as a continuation of the perimeter fence for other animal enclosures housed within the facility
that require a perimeter fence, and are centrally located within the facility.
The facility extended the height of the frame along the front of the primary enclosure to meet 72 inches, but did not
heighten the back side of the enclosure which slopes down and measures 43 inches and protrudes outside the perimeter
fence itself.
Having a perimeter fence in place protects the animals in the facility by restricting animals and unauthorized persons from
going through it or under it, permitting contact with the animals in the facility. Additionally, it serves as a secondary
containment system for the animals in the facility. The perimeter fence must be of sufficient distance from the outside of
the primary enclosure to prevent physical contact between animals inside the enclosure and animals or persons outside
the perimeter fence. Non-dangerous animals housed in outdoor facilities require a 6-foot-tall perimeter fence around their
enclosure and must be at least 3-feet away from any enclosures or buildings, unless an approved variance has been
issued in writing by the Administrator.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
The facility’s written environmental enhancement plan does not include the chickens and ducks on-hand at the facility.
Maintaining a documented plan ensures adequate provisions are in place to suitably promote and sustain the
psychological well-being and needs of the avian species housed. An enrichment plan must be developed, documented,
followed, and approved by the attending veterinarian, in accordance with the regulations in this subpart and currently
accepted professional standards.
This is a 2nd Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 1 more inspection or by December 30th, 2023 or the applicant will forfeit the
license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License
Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
3.127(d)  Repeat
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
The perimeter fence line adjacent to one primary enclosure at the facility still remains less than six feet tall. This vacant 
primary enclosure serves as a continuation of the perimeter fence for other animal enclosures housed within the facility 
that require a perimeter fence, and are centrally located within the facility.  
The facility extended the height of the frame along the front of the primary enclosure to meet 72 inches, but did not 
heighten the back side of the enclosure which slopes down and measures 43 inches and protrudes outside the perimeter 
fence itself. 
Having a perimeter fence in place protects the animals in the facility by restricting animals and unauthorized persons from 
going through it or under it, permitting contact with the animals in the facility. Additionally, it serves as a secondary 
containment system for the animals in the facility. The perimeter fence must be of sufficient distance from the outside of 
the primary enclosure to prevent physical contact between animals inside the enclosure and animals or persons outside 
the perimeter fence. Non-dangerous animals housed in outdoor facilities require a 6-foot-tall perimeter fence around their 
enclosure and must be at least 3-feet away from any enclosures or buildings, unless an approved variance has been 
issued in writing by the Administrator. 
3.154 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
The facility’s written environmental enhancement plan does not include the chickens and ducks on-hand at the facility. 
Maintaining a documented plan ensures adequate provisions are in place to suitably promote and sustain the 
psychological well-being and needs of the avian species housed. An enrichment plan must be developed, documented, 
followed, and approved by the attending veterinarian, in accordance with the regulations in this subpart and currently 
accepted professional standards. 
 
This is a 2nd Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 1 more inspection or by December 30th, 2023 or the applicant will forfeit the

license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License 
Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
